detail.content: Topics: Financial Crises                                Department of Economics      New York University               DOUGLAS GALE                   FINANCIAL CRISES       V31-0370004   Spring semester 2006            General information    Instructor: Douglas Gale       110 Fifth Avenue, 411     <douglas.gale@nyu.edu>  Lectures:             Monday and Wednesday, 3:30 - 4:45 PM, 569 Waverly         Office hours:           Monday and Wednesday, 2:00 - 3:00  Teaching assistant: Gulseren Mutlu   110 Fifth Avenue, 448    <gm590@nyu.edu>  TA office hours:           TBA     The prerequisites for the course are Intermediate Macroeconomics and Intermediate Microeconomics. Familiarity with the material contained in a course like “Money and Banking” would be helpful. The course will involve the use of mathematical models of risk and optimal risk-sharing to develop and analyze models of asset-price volatility, intermediation, financial fragility, optimal regulation, bubbles, contagion, and other topics.    The requirements of the course include           regular attendance at lectures beginning January 18.     satisfactory completion of weekly assignments     satisfactory completion of three midterm examinations.     The assessment for the course will be based primarily on the midterm examinations, but some weight will also be give to homework and attendance.     The course will be based on a book manuscript Understanding Financial Crises  (written with Franklin Allen of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania). Chapters and problem sets will be distributed via the web. Although the course is intended to be self contained and we shall develop tools and models as we need them, students are assumed to be familar with basic the material in a good Intermediate Microeconomics text such as Varian's Intermediate Microeconomics (W.W. Norton, 1999). Familiarity with the contents of a money and banking text, such as Hubbard's Money, the Financial System, and the Economy (Addison Wesley, 2004) or Mishkin's Economics of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets (Addison Wesley, 2003), would be helpful.     Outline         History and institutions      Time, uncertainty and liquidity     Present values and interest rates; intertemporal budget constraints; value maximization; efficient intertemporal allocation; the separation theorem.        States of nature, contingent commodities, and efficient sharing of risk; expected utility and risk aversion; risk pooling and insurance; complete markets and Arrow securities.    Liquidity preference, the yield curve (liquidity-return tradeoff), the efficient provision of liquidity.         Intermediation       Efficient sharing of idiosyncratic risks; intermediation,  contracting and competition; banking panics.          Asset markets         Liquidity preference, cash-in-the-market pricing, and asset-price volatility; inefficient market provision of liquidity; incomplete market participation and multiple equilibria.       Financial fragility        Aggregate risk and endogenous default; the backward bending supply curve; asset-price volatility and default;  sunspots versus real business cycle shocks .        Intermediation and financial markets        Complete markets, complete contracts, and incomplete participation; incomplete contracts and optimal financial crises.        The theory of optimal regulation        Incomplete markets and inefficient liquidity provision;  regulation of liquidity; optimal capital structure and risk sharing; complete markets and the Modigliani-Miller theorem;  incomplete markets and optimal capital structure .        Money and the price level        Optimal financial crises; optimal currency crises;  dollarization .         Bubbles and crises        Contagion        Government, bankruptcy and crises                    Course schedule and materials     Jan 18 and 23  Reading  Chap01 History and Institutions    Bordo et al    Bordo et al appendix    Wilson Sylla Jones    Bordo and Eichengreen    Bordo and Eichengreen appendix       Problem Set 1     Jan 25 and 30  Read the first section of Chap02 on intertemporal decisions. NYU's approach to the health of our students is one of “wellness”: supporting students in all aspects of their lives in order to enable them to achieve academic success. We believe this approach works well for our campus.  However, the demands of academic life, coupled with work, family, community, and personal responsibilities can create a stressful environment for students. We know how devoted and concerned our faculty and staff are about the well-being of our students, and we want to provide you with guidance on how to respond in cases of student mental distress.            Wellness Exchange   We believe students often can benefit from professional help in understanding and adjusting to the changes they are experiencing and coping with problems they may encounter. Our principal mechanism to provide access to these services is the Wellness Exchange. The Wellness Exchange is NYU's extensive network of health and mental health resources .    A 24/7 hotline ( 212-443-9999 ) centrally links all of these services and puts students in touch with professionals who can help them address day-to-day challenges as well as other health-related concerns including medical issues, academic stress, depression, sexual assault, anxiety, alcohol and other drug dependence, sexually transmitted infections, and eating disorders. The Wellness Exchange can provide assistance in both emergency and non-emergency situations.   The Wellness Exchange provides a variety of entry points to its services to accommodate student choice. Students can seek counseling by appointment at the Counseling Service, by calling the Wellness Exchange hotline, or by using walk-in services located at the Student Health Center (726 Broadway). Counseling is also available within some of the schools in offices located in school buildings.     In case of a life threatening emergency that is imminent (i.e., someone is holding or says they have a weapon and is threatening to use it), please call 911 immediately and then NYU Public Safety (212) 998-2222.   If a student expresses (either verbally or in written work) thoughts or impulses to hurt him/herself or impulses to harm others without any immediate, visible plan or intent, keep the student where he or she is, call the Wellness Exchange at (212) 443-9999 and request an urgent assessment.   If the student is not at imminent risk, but you are worried about the student’s or the community’s well-being, please reach out to the Wellness Exchange in order to seek advice on how to help the student.         Venezuela in Crisis and Context                                                                Venezuela in Crisis and Context   Feb 20, 2015                                   | 3:00 PM-8:00 PM                                     Shortages, food lines, blackouts, protests – two years after the death of firebrand President Hugo Chávez, Venezuela faces a perfect storm of social, political, and economic crises, pitting a still-diffuse project of Bolivarian socialism that was to be Chávez’s legacy, against the pressures of a petro-state in the midst of a dramatic oil bust. To help examine Venezuela’s current conjuncture, NYU’s Gallatin School of Individualized Study is proud to host three prominent Caracas-based scholars for a one-day symposium examining the country’s past, present, and future. Individual sessions on the country’s upstart communes, perilous prisons, and democratic traditions will be followed by a plenary discussion assessing short and long term scenarios for Venezuela. Free and open to the public; may attend any and/or all sessions.     Schedule:   3:00-4:00PM D emocracia a la venezolana: ¿Un sueño de dos siglos?*   TOMÁS STRAKA (Universidad Católica Andrés Bello; Fulbright Fellow, Pomona College)   Comment: Tony Spanakos (Montclair State University)   4:00-5:00PM The Venezuelan Prison: From Neoliberalism to the Bolivarian Revolution   ANDRÉS ANTILLANO (Universidad Central de Venezuela)   Comment: Naomi Schiller (Brooklyn College)   5:30-6:30PM Exclusionary-Inclusion and the incorporation of Popular Sectors in Venezuela under Chavismo   MARÍA PILAR GARCÍA GUADILLA (Universidad Simón Bolívar; Visiting Scholar, Tulane University)   Comment: George Ciccariello-Maher (Drexel University)   6:30-8:00PM Venezuela’s Crises: Roundtable and Q&A  with Julie Skurski (CUNY Graduate Center), María Pilar García-Guadilla, Tomás Straka, and Andrés Antillano   *Presentation in Spanish     Democracia a la venezolana: ¿Un sueño de dos siglos?*   TOMÁS STRAKA  Professor of History, Universidad Católica Andrés Bello  Fulbright Fellow, Pomona College   A pesar de las tensiones políticas e inmensos problemas económicos que Venezuela viene experimentando desde hace tres décadas, la democracia sigue apareciendo como un valor en el que los venezolanos parecen seguir creyendo. Es algo que puede sorprender sobre todo si consideramos que para muchos sectores se trata de un modelo muy distante de la realidad venezolana. Probablemente una respuesta esté en su análisis en clave histórica, aproximándonos a lo que los venezolanos mayoritariamente hemos entendido por democracia desde el siglo XIX.   The Venezuelan Prison: From Neoliberalism to the Bolivarian Revolution   ANDRÉS ANTILLANO  Professor of Criminology, Universidad Central de Venezuela   This presentation considers two related ideas. On the one hand, how to explain the rise of criminal punishment in Bolivarian Venezuela, which runs contrary to what research on the relationship between neoliberalism, inequality, and punitive law predicts (punishment increases under neoliberalism and decreases under progressive regimes). On the other hand, how to describe prison life, which reproduces neoliberal logic inside through de facto privatization, exploitation and biopolitical regimentation, rigidity and suffering of the dispossessed.   Exclusionary-Inclusion and the incorporation of Popular Sectors in Venezuela under Chavismo   MARÍA PILAR GARCÍA GUADILLA  Professor of Sociology and Urban Studies, Universidad Simón Bolívar  Visiting Research Scholar, Tulane University   Venezuela’s development plans, public policies and strategies of social organization for the incorporation of poor sectors under Chavismo could be defined as “exclusionary” because they do not take into account all constitutional rights, ethnic groups, social classes, political institution and ideological affiliations. They have stress an Extractive economy that neglects the rights of indigeneous communities, favored the socio-economic rights over the civic and political ones; privileged direct assembly decisions with the displacement and even substitution of existing institutions of representative democracy and, excluded the middle-class and social actors and organizations not aligned ideologically with the Bolivarian Revolutionary Project.
